fact: The low, resounding calls elephants make can be heard by another elephant up to 5 miles (8 kilometers) away.
Each bird in the exhibit wears a colorful wing band, which helps Academy staff and visitors quickly distinguish one bird from another. Males are banded on the right, females on the left.
African penguins molt once a year. During this time, they lose all of their feathers and grow a new set
One of its most distinctive features is a small pink gland above each eye, which helps them cope with high temperatures in South Africa.
The African penguin (Spheniscus demersus) – it’s the only penguin known to live along the southern coasts of Africa today.
The sex of alligator hatchlings is determined by the temperature of the nest during incubation. Warmer temperatures produce males, while cooler temperatures produce females
While African male and female elephants both have tusks, Asian female elephants do not.
Research on wild endangered Asian elephants is difficult and sparse, and zoo elephants are valuable sources of knowledge.
The species exhibited in the Seabird Aviary are Tufted Puffins, Horned Puffins, Rhinoceros Auklets, Pigeon Guillemots, Common Murres and Black Oystercatchers.

You can tell the two species apart by their distinctive features: Hamadryas are tan-haired with red faces and rears, while Geladas have dark colored faces with light eyelids and a red hourglass-shaped patch of skin on their chests.
Beluga whales use echolocation to find prey in murky water
Kelp forests provide shelter, food, and breeding grounds for many species, including other algae, marine mammals, fish, birds, invertebrates, and plankton.
Instead of making its nest in the hollow of a tree, as most owls do, it finds a home in abandoned prairie dog burrows or rattlesnake dens. The owl uses its long legs for further excavating.
California sea lions can smell on land, but not underwater
Accelerating from zero to 45 in just 2.5 seconds, it is the fastest land mammal and can reach top speeds of 60 to 70 mph (69 to 112 kilometers per hour).
Chimpanzees and humans have DNA that is 98% the same. Chimps are more closely related to humans than they are to orangutans.
the California condor population was almost wiped out by the destruction of habitat, poaching, and lead poisoning.
Dingoes spend most of their life solitary, but will occasionally form packs of 3-10 individuals. These packs range from casual hunting groups to close-knit family packs.
Fiordland Penguins breed only in New Zealand and can swim up to a remarkable 7000kms in search of food
The pink color of a flamingo comes from their diet; in the wild, small crustaceans they eat give them their color.
Macaroni penguins are excellent climbers and are known as the “alpine penguin” because they will scale cliff faces to find nesting areas.
An adult panda is roughly 900 times bigger than a new-born cub
As few as 1,864 giant pandas live in their native habitat, while another 600 pandas live in zoos and breeding centers around the world.
Giant pandas are solitary, with males and females coming together only briefly to mate.
Dominance between males is established by swinging heads at one another and intertwining necks in tests of strength.
Giraffes communicate through snorts, grunts and grumbling.
Giraffes may eat up to 75 pounds (34 kilograms) of food per day, nibbling on leaves from Africa’s acacia trees.

Though inland grizzly bears follow a seasonal diet mainly consisting of vegetation, Yellowstone grizzlies are an exception. Up to 95% of their energy intake is from meat because in the park fruit is rare while there are many ungulates.
Despite their impressive size, grizzlies are quite fast and have been clocked at 30 miles (48 kilometers) an hour.
Harbor seals can dive up to 1,500 feet below the surface and remain underwater for close to 30 minutes while hunting for food
Hippos can even hold their breath underwater for more than five minutes at a time.
They don’t have true sweat glands; instead, hippos secrete a thick, red substance from their pores known as "blood sweat," as it looks like the animal is sweating blood.
In this colorful gallery, children finally “find Nemo,” as well as seahorses, fairy basslets, yellow-head jawfish and other jewels of the sea.
A large group of jellies is called a smack
Giant kelp provides food and shelter for a vibrant ecosystem
Koalas normally sleep between 18 and 22 hours a day! They carry no body fat and their diet is lacking nutrition, so they conserve every bit of energy for essential movement and body functions

The fur on koala bottoms are densely packed to ‘cushion’ the branches they sit on, and they have a bony cartilage under the skin which is perfectly formed for sitting in the "V" shape of tree branches.
Eucalyptus leaves have strong-smelling oils that make koalas smell a bit like menthol cough drops.
They are slightly smaller than African lions and the males don’t develop such a substantial mane
The world's most social felines, lions roam the savannas and grasslands of the African continent, hunting cooperatively and raising cubs in prides.
On average, the length of time a lion is in control of a pride is 2–3 years. Competition among males to take over a pride can be ferocious!
Magellanic Penguins build their nests during the breeding season along the rocky, sandy beaches of the southern coasts of Argentina and Chile and on the Falkland Islands.
All birds lose feathers and grow new ones, but penguins have adapted to molt and regrow all their feathers at once.

While the family is out foraging, one or more meerkats will take on the duty to keep an eye out for predators. If danger is spotted, the sentinel will alarm the group with a distinctive bark so that the others can hide in their burrows.
If they feed extensively on crustaceans, they’ll turn pink or lavender. An orange tint hints that they’ve been feeding on brine shrimp.
Moon jellyfish, Aurelia aurita, can be found in every ocean on Earth but no one is really certain of their origin.
Naked mole-rats live underground and are the only true eusocial mammals, spending their lives in large colonies with a single breeding female.
You'll see giant tuna power their way through the water, while pelagic rays and green sea turtles swim just inches away.
As the largest tree-dwelling mammals in the world, the beautiful Bornean orangutan is found in Southeast Asia's rainforests.
Orangutan arms stretch out longer than their bodies—over 7 feet (2 meters) from fingertip to fingertip.

specific: gentoo, king, and northern rockhopper penguins
fact: You may spot Kevin, our naughtiest penguin, who has a lifetime ban from the penguin parade for pecking at our visitors!
Native to the outlying areas around Antarctica, the King can dive up to 1,000 feet under water to hunt for fish.
Reaching an impressive 2.5 metres in length (8 ft 2 in), the perentie is Australia’s largest lizard, and the fourth biggest lizard in the world.
Although corals are tiny organisms, they construct some of the largest and most ecologically important structures in the world.
Red Piranhas are highly predaceous carnivores that scavenge for food; consuming insects, snails, worms, plants and even nipping the fins of other fishes
Platypus are Australian mammals and belong to the Monotreme family, which means they are mammals which lay eggs.
Adult male platypuses have venomous spurs, an unusual characteristic among mammals, used to defend mates and territory from rival males.
Polar bears display an amazing ability to stalk seals and wait patiently for them to surface through their breathing holes or leads (open areas) in the sea ice.
A polar bear can swim at a speed of up to 6 miles per hour (8 knots).
Puffin colonies have now become tourist attractions in parts of their range.
This saltwater exhibit, home to thousands of colorful reef fish, big, toothy sharks and a rescued green sea turtle, is designed to model the Flower Garden Banks National Marine Sanctuary.
Rays are part of a group of fish called elasmobranchs, whose skeletons are made of soft, flexible cartilage, while the other fish in the lagoon are teleosts, or bony fishes.
White rhinos aren’t white. The ‘white’ is taken from the Afrikaans word ‘weit’ meaning ‘wide’ – they were describing the rhino’s mouth.
Naturally found only on the island of Madagascar, the ring-tailed lemur is diurnal - meaning that it is mostly active in the daylight hours.
Otters use special flaps to close off their nostrils and ears when underwater.
Found along the coasts of California and Oregon, these sea jellies feed on small fish and plankton that come in contact with the jellies’ stinging tentacles.
It hunts tiny drifting animals by trailing those long tentacles and frilly mouth-arms, all covered with stinging cells. When the tentacles touch prey, the stinging cells paralyze it and stick tight.
It’s been popularly accepted that jellies are simple yet pretty gelatinous blobs that float around at the mercy of currents but science shows that they are so much more sophisticated than we think.
Sea otters balance their prey on their chest and open it with a rock
t’s a keystone species, which means that the health of sea otters is a good indication of the health of other species and ecosystems nearby.
In the wild, sea otters sometimes “hold hands”—or, more accurately, paws—while sleeping so they don’t drift away from their raft (the term for a group of resting sea otters).
The sea otters at the Vancouver Aquarium were rescued when they were just babies. They were so young that they didn’t know how to eat by themselves or groom themselves yet.
This exhibit features more than 150 sharks including sand tiger, zebra, and white tip reef sharks!
Our Ocean Voyager gallery is home to whale sharks, manta rays and thousands of other fascinating fish.
Explore the waters of Monterey Bay, where sharks glide through the deep reef, giant sea bass lumber among the reef pilings and flatfish nestle in the sandy seafloor
This area is alive with five species of shark, huge bat rays and great schools of anchovy and mackerel.
When threatened Hosmer's skinks wedge themselves in between the rocks and puff out their spikey bodies, making them very hard to remove.
Their thick, patterned fur coat keeps them warm and helps them to blend into their rocky habitat.
They are probably most well-known, although it is just one group, for the habit of sitting in natural hot springs in order to escape the winter extremes.
Sumatran tigers live alone in the wild and are quite shy, so don’t worry if you can’t see Dharma.
Each tiger has its very own stripe pattern. Researchers who observe tigers can identify individuals by their unique stripes.
This exhibit represents the famous Blue Corner off the coast of Palau.

The life-rich aquatic ecosystem of the Indo-Pacific includes The Coral Triangle. This marine area contains nearly 600 species of reef-building corals and is home for more than 2,000 species of reef fish.
Sloths are nocturnal. That means they sleep during the day and hang out at night.
Gorillas have unique noseprints and fingerprints. Scientists use noseprints to identify gorillas in the wild.
